title: 105_s1759
content: The American GI Forum of the United States, a nonprofit corporation organized under the laws of Texas, is recognized and granted a Federal charter. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its bylaws and articles of incorporation filed in Texas. The American GI Forum of the United States, a nonprofit corporation, aims to uphold American democracy, defend the Constitution, promote equal opportunities, and encourage minority participation in policy-making. The American GI Forum of the United States aims to combat prejudicial practices, promote cultural heritage, and ensure equal opportunities for all citizens. The American GI Forum of the United States follows Texas laws for service of process, membership eligibility, board composition, and officer responsibilities. SEC. 7. OFFICERS. The positions of officers and election of members shall be as per the bylaws, articles of incorporation, and Texas laws. SEC. 8. RESTRICTIONS. The corporation's income and assets cannot benefit any member, officer, or director, except for reasonable compensation and approved expenses. No loans can be made to any individual within the corporation. The issuance of stock or payment of dividends is prohibited. The corporation cannot claim Congressional or Federal approval for its activities. The corporation, organized under Texas law, functions as an educational and research organization. Membership and leadership roles cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, disability, age, or national origin. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers, directors, employees, and agents within their authority. Maintenance and inspection of books and records are required. SEC. 10. The corporation must maintain accurate books and records of account and keep a record of members' names and addresses. Members have the right to inspect these records for any proper purpose. SEC. 11. Financial transactions are subject to audit. SEC. 11 amends the Act to include the American GI Forum of the United States. SEC. 12 requires the corporation to submit an annual report to Congress. SEC. 13 reserves the right for Congress to alter, amend, or repeal the Act. SEC. 14 mandates tax-exempt status as a condition of the charter. SEC. 14 mandates tax-exempt status as a condition of the charter, and the charter will terminate if the corporation fails to maintain this status. SEC. 15 states that the charter will expire if the corporation fails to comply with any provisions of the Act. SEC. 16 defines "State" to include specific territories and possessions of the United States.
